comments.author: Brionatic

comments.text:
If it is this easy to just kill all the other rivals, then why not just do 
that in the beginning?﻿
comments.author: toad g

comments.text:
+toad g the Commission, namely the meeting of Dons in the conference room, 
decided to keep the peace by letting each Don take a particular business 
and territory. Vito had no reason to kill the others because they had no 
reason to kill him either. It was when narcotics became an issue that they 
all consipired to either convince him or kill him as his sucessor might 
agree to sharing the Corloene's hold on politicians and the police.

The killings are Vito and Michael's idea as they seem to have no allies in 
New York any longer, and the peace is completely broken with the Barzinis 
killing Sonny and Vito himself almost killed by Barzini hitmen, and Michael 
losing his first wife to a Barzini car bomb in Sicily. While earlier Don 
Corleone could live peacefully among the other Dons (who attended Connie's 
wedding in the beginning), they then threatened his family, so retaliation 
was ultimately necessary.

The 'peace conference' meeting in the movie was about the loss of Sonny 
Corleone and Bruno Tattaglia and peace, but when Barzini pushed the 
narcotics issue instead Vito then realized that he wasn't treated as an 
equal any longer and that the other four Dons would try to take the power 
he wouldn't give them.
comments.author: SantomPh

comments.text:
I just seen this movie for the first time. And i really have a hard time 
understanding and grasping even the smallest things just cause it's alot to 
take it in and put together.

who were all the people killed in this scene? And what did they do? Can 
somone explain this to me in detail from the begginning please :(.﻿
comments.author: bubbaXzone

comments.text:
+bubbaXzone 

They're the dons of 4 rival families, the Corleone's take them all out in a 
decapitation strike. Once Don Vito Corleone died, the fragile peace he 
negotiated with the other families was over.

In the book, just two of them got killed: Barzini and Tattaglia, who 
conspired to kill Michael, and previously, killed his brother Santino. 

The other guy is Moe Greene, a character from the Vegas subplot. In the 
book, he was killed way earlier.

One of my favorite series of scenes in the whole movie. I get chills when 
this plays. The way it cuts to the church scene back to the hits is eerie. 
While Michael is at his nephew's baptism, you have the assassinations 
taking place at the same time. The music heightens it up even more. It's 
just so brilliant.﻿

comments.author: Leon Delvechio Ramirez

comments.text:
This scene itself shows a stark contrast between Michael and Vito. Fate was 
actually with Vito in a way. He was a man with moral values and the mafia 
world was throwing all those values out and turning towards dirtiness. And 
as the mafia with codes and moral values came to an end, so did Vito 
Corleone. Never did Vito Corleone wish to see things or the mafia world go 
this way and never did he actually see it go this way.﻿
comments.author: saad afzal

comments.text:
+saad afzal these people had planned to remove the Corleone family from the 
New York crime empire altogether now that Vito and Sonny were dead. These 
killings are the result of the actions of the Five Families organization 
gobbling up Corleone territory and turning Tessio into a traitor as well as 
Don Barzini making things personal by trying to kill Vito, killing 
Apollonia, suppporting Tattaglia (and therefore Solozzo). Moe Greene was 
beating back the Corloenes in Vegas and as a member of Murder Inc. had to 
be eliminated if the Corleones were going to settle in Nevada.

your Don Corleone with morals won his territory by beating another gangster 
in the brutal Olive Oil War prior to events in the Godfather. He used Luca 
Brasi as his assassin without hesitation.

We see how Don Vito loved his children and his closest associates, but he 
too knew when to get rid of his enemies. He was Michael's consigliere when 
the war against the Tattaglias was the worst, and the killings of the other 
Dons are his idea as he knows their sucessors are not as strong as his own 
son Michael and will sue for peace, leaving the Corleones as number 1.

In the book, Cuneo and Stracci do not die and become allies of the 
Corleones even though they did conspire with Barzini and Tattaglia to take 
Corleone turf initially. The movie kills them all because it would be hard 
to explain this after the meeting of the Dons earlier seemed to gang up on 
Vito.
comments.author: SantomPh

comments.text: So, Vito is a mafia version of Dominic. Both of them have the code
comments.author: Arnold Triyudho

comments.text:
+Potato Sack 100% Correct, I think Vito knew with him sick and on his way 
out he wanted Michael with as clean an open road as he could by whacking 
the other family heads. Why do you think Michael removed Tom as 
Consigliere, he told him "things may get rough with the move". They were 
planning the murders for awhile.
comments.author: Mikeymike301

comments.text:
Actually..... It was Michael AND Vito that planned these hits together, not 
Michael alone. Mafia with values?......yeah
comments.author: Potato Sack

comments.text:
Great observation, Saad. You reminded me how at the very beginning of the 
move, Vito refused the undertaker's request to have the people who bashed 
and raped his daughter killed - "We're not murderers'. That's not as ironic 
as it might sound: Vito valued human life and didn't condone the murder of 
'civilians' ... and Mob-related deaths he considered casualties of war, not 
murders.
comments.author: John Camilleri

comments.text:
When you think about it the murders are really a better reference to the 
behavior of the Church even than they are to that of any organized crime 
syndicate.﻿
comments.author: Robert Miles

comments.text:
Frances Ford Coppola won the Best Director Oscar for 'The Godfather Part 2' 
& rightly so, but watching this breathtaking scene, I actually think he 
might possibly have deserved it even more for 'The Godfather' - Especially 
considering all the shit he had to take from the Paramount Studio 
Executives who were apparently planning to fire him and replace him with 
the 2nd director.
-Frances however fire the 2nd director along with several others trechorous 
crew members as a preemptive strike, which sent the Executives into a panic 
and meant they couldn't fire Frances!!

 Frances Ford Coppola is basically Michael Corleone without all the murder 
etc.﻿
comments.author: Axe423

comments.text: So true they only gave him two fucking days for the wedding scene!!!
comments.author: Warrior Chicken

comments.text:
Clemenza kills Victor Stracci and an associate with a shot gun, Rocco 
Lampone and a fellow button man kill Philip Tattalia and the prostitute he 
is banging in a hail of machine gun fire, Willie Cicci shoots dead Carmine 
Cuneo by trapping him in the revolving door and Al Neri shoots dead Emile 
Barzini on the steps having already shot dead his body guard and driver.

Who kills Mo Greene?? - Maybe that could be Frankie Pentangelli as you dont 
get to see the guy who shoot's Moe from the front, and from the back it 
could pass as Frankie 5 angels - even though the character didn't even 
exist at that point, and was invented simply as a replacement for Clemenza 
in GF 2!!!!!!!﻿
comments.author: Axe423

comments.text:
+StrasbergProtégé Yeah they made a lot of changes in the film to what was 
in the novel - that was certainly one of them, as all the assassinations 
took place on the same day, which was deliberate (i.e. to catch them all of 
guard).
Moe Green was certainly not killed by Neri in the film, so I reckon with a 
kind of hindsight Frank Pentangelli would have been the man for the job - 
although the character didn't exists in GF P1!!


Michael seemed to want to use his most trusted, high ranking men. Even Tom 
Hagan played a bit part in the scheme to set up Tessio for assassination, 
although it was a group of button men who took Tessio away to be shot.
comments.author: Axe423

comments.text:
+MortyBoy15
Yeah I read that also - I reckon Michael WOULD have used Frank Pentangelli 
(if he had actually existed in GF1), cos for those killings he used his 
most trusted, and high up men, rather than just button men. - Neri to kill 
Barzini, Rocco to kill D'Talia, Clemenza to kill Stacci and then Carlo, 
Clemenza selected chief button man Cicci to kill cuneo and also take charge 
of the group of button men who would dispose of Tessio (with the 
co-operation of Tom Hagan) - I reckon a high up guy like Pentangelli would 
have been used to kill Moe Greene. - In fact from the rear, then unknown 
assassin who shoots Moe Green in the film could possibly pass for Frank 
Pentangelli.
comments.author: Axe423

comments.text:
+Axe423 I've now read the novel, and it looks like Al Neri shot both in the 
novel since they were not killed on the same day there, but they were 
killed on the same day in the film version (probably for dramatic 
purposes), so I guess they just put an unknown assassin in the film to kill 
Moe Greene
comments.author: StrasbergProtégé

comments.text:
+MortyBoy15 Yeah I read that - I think that is how it is in the novel, but 
the film is different as Al Neri shoots dead Barzini instead (as they are 
all killed on the same day).

You don't actually get to see from the front who kills Moe Green, but from 
the back it looks like a middle age, stocky guy and could in retrospect 
pass for Frank Pentangelli. - In all probability, if the character had of 
existed in GF 1, Pentangelii would have been used to kill one of the Dons 
or Moe Green, The reason being that Michael wanted his very top, most 
trusted and capable men to carry out that crucial operation. Thats why he 
used Rocco to kill Detallia, Neri to kill Barxini, Clemenza to kill Stracci 
and Clemenza's chief soldier Will Cicci to kill Cuneo.

Michael was able to give those kind of orders as he was already fully 
respected by his men, having made his own bones by personally taking out 
Sollozo and Police Captain Mcclusky in a crucially important killing for 
the family before.
comments.author: Axe423

comments.text:
According to The Godfather wikia, Al Neri also assassinated Moe Greene one 
month after Michael was in Las Vegas
comments.author: StrasbergProtégé

comments.text:
+SantomPh and Moe Greene let it slip that he was negotiating with Barzini 
about his casino business. The five families with Barzini as the mastermind

skimming from the Corleone family and they knew it but when he blurted out 
the negotiation with Barzinin and making statements about the Corleones 
being all washed up he was going to go down .
comments.author: eugene poteet

comments.text:
+Robert Gift Dons rarely have innocent drivers- Vito Corleone had Paulie 
Gatto as his personal chauffeur,after all (and he got killed being 
Clemenza's driver). All of Barzini's men had to die that day.

The woman was one of Tattaglia's prostitutes. Rocco and Aldo Trapani had to 
come in and shock him immediately with a swift attack.

This is war, declared by the Five Families on the Corleones.

comments.text:
They probably wouldn't have known for certain that the 'chauffeur' was just 
a 'chauffeur' - maybe they didn't know if he was also on the Barzini 
payroll or not and carried a gun also. Its unlikely Barzini would use a 
chauffeur hire service, so any guy driving Barzini around would likely have 
to be armed also.

Phillip Tattalia who was shot in the bed, was a well know pimp, and the 
woman was likely to be one of his prostitutes. That being the case she 
would have been on the Tattlia payroll, and prostitutes can often have a 
close bond with their pimps. The is a good chance that Tattalia had a gun 
nearby, so if they didn't shoot the pros, then maybe she would grab a gun 
and return fire.

comments.text:
There are actually a few connections between the Godfather and Star Wars. 
George Lucas had been an assistant of Francis Ford Coppola at his 
production company, and it was Lucas who told Coppola he had to direct the 
Godfather because the company was nearing bankruptcy.

comments.text:
Starting at 0:13, the organ piece is the Adagio section of Bach's Prelude 
in D Major, BWV 532. In my opinion, its some of the most beautiful organ 
music ever written.﻿

comments.text:
What a facade. I've always hated the religion aspect of this movie. Roman 
Catholicism has nothing to do with the these animals. There is no excuse 
for this kind of behavior. Live decently, if it means to live poor and 
humble, so be it. At the very least you can look yourself in the mirror.﻿
comments.author: inutero10

comments.text:
+inutero10 "Roman Catholicism has nothing to do with the these animals." 
You're joking right? Or have you forgotten about the millions slaughtered 
over the centuries by Catholic convert-or-die escapades. Or even the 
millions slaughtered by Catholic we-just-need-to-steal-your-land 
adventures? How about the thousands of burned 'witches' and 'heretics'? No? 
You can't have forgotten the Inquisition's red hot poker through the eye 
blinding techniques (to achieve 'conversion') surely? Actually, that last 
one is very Moe Green ;)

comments.text:
You can interpret the baptism scene as Michael's "baptism" - he is reborn 
in the blood of his rivals and accepts deception and murder as constants in 
his life. It's a bit ham-fisted, but still powerful.

comments.author: TrollingOn1

comments.text:
+Malachi Coleman Why would Michael need an alibi if he didn't partake in 
the murders? He was at a baptism ceremony for his sister's, Connie, baby's 
baptism. He could easily be anywhere else, but being at the church was 
important for this scene because what do you symbolically do at a baptism? 
You wash yourself of all your sins. What was occurring between this scene? 
It's a duality. From my perspective, I'm not looking at this scene from a 
literal point of view. I'm looking at the symbology this scene is covered 
in and Michael Corleone's duality.
comments.author: salg

comments.text: +salg it's not really hypocrisy, him being in church was an alibi.

comments.text:
True Christianity preaches repentance is necessary for absolution. 
Repeating a phrase over and over, counting beads, or putting some extra 
money in the church plate is not repentance. You must truly feel the guilt 
of what you've done, and not just because you are being held accountable 
for it. Then you must truly turn away from sinful behaviors. Those two 
actions together constitute repentance, and then you can ask to be 
forgiven. This works on any level, be it human or spiritual. Recognizing 
your guilt, admitting it, feeling truly bad for it, making the decision to 
not do it again, then being forgiven by the one you've offended. Michael 
ain't sorry for shit. LoL.﻿

comments.text:
Barzini's murder was made in very risky way. What it he survived the 
wounds? After all, Don Vito got 5 bullets on him, and still made it out.. 
and Barzini, the most dangerous and powerful one, got only two... leaving 
him w/out a control shot was real risky..﻿
comments.author: BlackCrowNavajo

comments.text:
+BlackCrowNavajo The guy could have had another piece hidden in his shoe if 
he ran out of shots in the first one or it jammed. It's happens often in 
mob circles to carry two guns.
comments.author: Nino Gaggi

comments.text:
+SantomPh this is all true and reasonable what you say. but nevertheless - 
I still believe  that Barzini's murder in the movie was performed in a 
highly risky and improbable way. For the screen purposes yes, it was 
effective and memorablel, but in reality it is highly unlikely that they 
would only spare one bullet for such dangerous target. remember how poor 
Andy Stone was killed in Casino?
comments.author: BlackCrowNavajo

comments.text:
+BlackCrowNavajo Neri was picked for Barzini specifically because he had a 
police uniform and had training in shooting properly. Also, he would 
certainly have had a man on top of the stairs making sure Barzini had 
nowhere to go. Neri actually went through some training with Clemenza 
before becoming Mike's right hand man- he was dubbed "your Luca (Brasi) " 
by Tom Hagen.
comments.author: SantomPh

comments.text: The bullets were "blunts," meaning they'd do maximum damage upon impact.
comments.author: Paul Harris

comments.text:
+ChemicallyImbalanced again, all correct. but - remember the epic phrase of 
Remo from an epic movie Casino? "listen, why take a chance? at least that's 
the way I see it"... and Andy Stone got whacked w/ no chance of survival..
comments.author: BlackCrowNavajo

comments.text:
I doubt that even if Barzini had survived, there wouldn't be much of a 
difference. Michael had eliminated the heads of 3 out of 4 of the other 
families. The infighting and disarray would make the families collapse, and 
the capos start killing each other for the top spots. A very injured 
Barzini in the hospital would probably be an easy target, if he'd survive 
(it's still the 1940s, medicine isn't like today)
And even IF he'd come out almost unharmed, would there really be that much 
trouble? 
Michael would quickly seize control of the other families, and Barzini's 
would get chased out of NY.
comments.author: Nino Gaggi

comments.text:
+BlackCrowNavajo It's more theatrically climactic and dramatic to see Don 
Barzini being shot from a distance, cringe his back in pain, and then see 
him roll down a flight of stone steps to his death. He was the main 
antagonist of the Corleone family throughout the whole film. But aside from 
that, he had a bodyguard, and he was smarter than Tattaglia or the rest. 
(You can tell by the way he's looking around that he always remains alert). 
So an elaborate scheme of Al Neri posing as a police officer and writing 
his driver a ticket was necessary to ensure the assassination would be a 
success. Even if Barzini would have made it inside Neri would probably have 
chased him down. (He was a lot younger). Once a don's bodyguard is 
neutralized, then it's usually easy hunting from there.
comments.author: brendan b

comments.text:
what you say is all correct, of course. Only, I doubt Neri had time to give 
such scientific analysis to his shots. What I'm saying is that the enemy No 
1 was murdered the way which had pretty high risk of incompleteness. Look 
at others' deaths - no chance of survival. after all, risk is calculated by 
probability of failure x impact of consequences. Had Barzini survived, you 
can imagine what would have his reaction be.
comments.author: BlackCrowNavajo

comments.text:
Look where the shots hit him. One went through the left side of his back 
which possible hit his heart, and the second one was directly in the spinal 
cord which is very fatal. And remember he fell down the stairs and hit his 
head. I have to say Al Neri is a very good shot. Vito was shot five times; 
most of the shots got him in the lower left and some got him in the arm, 
and he was shot in street. No stairs. So Vito was very lucky.

comments.author: Stephen Andrano

comments.text:
+Stephen Andrano Vito was not almost killed by his own brother, and Carlo 
was a completely abusive husband and useless father as well, and he openly 
helped Barzini kill Sonny. Oh no, Carlo had to die. Fredo could have 
redeemed himself by not taking Johnny Ola's offer and going straight to 
Michael, who would have protected him. Carlo could have just taken Don 
Corleone's small sports book and given Connie a good living and prove to 
Vito that he was a capable man- that would have given him a reward 
eventually, and acceptance into the family.

That's one constant folly in the Godfather movies, when people have a 
problem they look for anyone other than the one man who could help them- 
namely Don Corleone.

comments.text:
I will make this clear. I have respect for the Iranian/Persian culture and 
all of its contributions. Currently, however, the country is ruled by the 
parties of God who gleefully look forward to apocalypse. I am therfore 
opposed to having a rogue theocracy access to nuclear weapons technology. 
No way. No how. Not while I am alive.
comments.author: 43nostromo

comments.text:
+43nostromo Apologies for bringing this back up again but if we go back to 
the Cold War; did the USSR genuinely want to annihilate the US from the 
face of the Earth? No. I know some Iranians and they are very intelligent 
and respectable people, the Islamic regime in Iran are trying to frighten 
the West. I don't know why they want access to plutonium but its likely 
that they wish to express their authority through destructive power. thats 
all
comments.author: ShyanTheLegend
